question: What happened in the days when Murtough Mac Erca was in the High Kingship of Ireland?
answer1: The country was divided between the old beliefs of paganism and the new doctrines of the Christian teaching.

question: Why was the thought of the people troubled?
answer1: They knew not which way to follow and which to forsake.

question: What did the new faith do every day?
answer1: spread wider and wider through the land

question: Who joined themselves to the Christian faith?
answer1: the family of Murtough

question: Who were the bishops and abbots of the Church?
answer1: Murtough's three brothers

question: Who remained a pagan?
answer1: Murtough

question: Why did Murtough remain a pagan?
answer1: He was a wild and lawless prince.
answer2: The peaceful teachings of the Christian doctrine, with its forgiveness of enemies, pleased him not at all.

question: Where was Murtough?
answer1: in the sunny summer palace of Cletty

question: Who was the son of Art?
answer1: Cormac

question: What did Cormac build for pleasure?
answer1: a pleasure house on the brink of the slow-flowing Boyne, near the Fairy Brugh of Angus the Ever Young, the God of Youth and Beauty

question: What did the king do when the high-noon came the sun grew hot?
answer1: sat down to rest upon the fairy mound

question: How did the witch look in face and form?
answer1: star-bright and beautiful

question: Whose name was "Sigh, Sough, Storm, Rough Wind, Winter Night, Cry, Wail, and Groan?"
answer1: a witch woman

question: Why did the witch hate Murtough?
answer1: He had scattered and destroyed the Ancient Peoples of the Fairy Tribes of Erin, her country and her fatherland.
answer2: n the battle which he fought at Cerb on the Boyne her father and her mother and her sister had been slain.

question: What would men call the fairy folk?
answer1: demons

question: Why did the witch wait the day to be revenged on Murtough?
answer1: He being yet a pagan, was still within her power to harm.

question: What would happen to the fairy folk's power and great majesty with the coming of the new faith?
answer1: Their power and their great majesty would depart from them.
answer2: Men would call them demons, and would drive them out with psalm-singing and with the saying of prayers, and with the sound of little tinkling bells.

question: How will the witch feel about what would happen to the fairy folk?
answer1: angry

question: What name did the men give the witch?
answer1: Sheen
answer2: "Storm"

question: Where was the King sitting?
answer1: on the fairy mound

question: What did Sheen don?
answer1: Her mantle of flowing green.

question: What happened after Sheen was decked?
answer1: Sheen went softly and sat down beside Murtough on the turfy hunting mound.

question: How did Murtough feel about Sheen's beauty?
answer1: wonder
answer2: terror

question: Why did Murtough not know if he loved or hated Sheen?
answer1: At one moment all his nature was filled with longing and with love of her, so that it seemed to him that he would give the whole of Ireland for the loan of one hour's space of dalliance with her; but after that he felt a dread of her, because he knew his fate was in her hands, and that she had come to work him ill.

question: How did Sheen know Murtough?
answer1: She was the beloved of Murtough.
answer2: All secret and mysterious things were known to her and thou and all the men of Erin were well known.

question: How did Murtough feel when Sheen told him she was his beloved?
answer1: glad

question: What happened after Murtough conversed with Sheen for a while?
answer1: She appeared to him so fair that the King was ready to promise her anything in life she wished, so long as she would go with him to Cletty of the Boyne.

question: Where did Murtough want Sheen to go with him?
answer1: Cletty of the Boyne

question: What did Sheen wish for?
answer1: take her to his house
answer2: put out from it his wife and his children because they were of the new faith, and all the clerics that were in his house
answer3: neither his wife nor any cleric be permitted to enter the house while she was there

question: Why did Murtough say it was easier to give his beloved half of Ireland than to follow her wishes?
answer1: Murtough feared that when those that were of the Christian faith were put out of his house, she would work her spells upon him, and no power would be left with him to resist those spells.

question: What did Sheen tell Murtough he must never do?
answer1: Her name must never be uttered, nor must any man or woman learn it.

question: Why did people call the witch "Sheen?"
answer1: for 'Storm'
answer2: her chief name
answer3: Storms were with her where she came.

question: What happened after Sheen told Murtough her name?
answer1: He brought her to his home, and drove out the clerics that were there, with his wife and children along with them, and drove out also the nobles of his own clan, the children of Niall, two great and gallant battalions.

question: Who was Murtough's wife?
answer1: Duivsech

question: Who did Duivsech seek?
answer1: Bishop Cairnech, the half-brother of her husband
answer2: her own soul-friend

question: Why did Duivsech seek her own soul-friend?
answer1: She might obtain help and shelter from him.

question: What happened when Sheen saw the house, nobles, and feasting?
answer1: Her heart was lifted within her, and "Fair as a fairy palace is this house of Cletty," said she.

question: What did the king do that night?
answer1: robed himself in all the splendour of his royal dignity

question: What did the men say about Sheen?
answer1: Never on earth was to be seen a woman more goodly of appearance than she.

question: Why did the astonished king begin to ask questions?
answer1: It seemed to him that the power of a great goddess of the ancient time was in her.

question: Why did the king ask if she believed in the God of the clerics or was some goddess of the older world?
answer1: He feared her, feeling that his fate was in her hands.

question: Why did Sheen laugh a careless and cruel laugh?
answer1: She knew that the King was in their power, now that she was there alone with him, and the clerics and the Christian teachers gone.

question: What did Sheen say she was?
answer1: like thee, a daughter of the race of men of the ancient family of Adam and of Eve; fit and meet my comradeship with thee

question: Who could Sheen call up to life?
answer1: men fiercely fighting in conflict

question: What happened to the water of the Boyne Sheen took?
answer1: She took of the water of the Boyne and made a magic wine thereout.

question: How did Sheen feed Murtough and the hosts?
answer1: She took ferns and spiked thistles and light puff-balls of the woods, and out of them she fashioned magic swine and sheep and goats.

question: What happened after Murtough and the hosts ate?
answer1: All their strength went from them.
answer2: The magic wine sent them into an uneasy sleep and restless slumbers.

question: Where did Sheen put one of the battalions?
answer1: at one side of the house
answer2: at the further side beyond it
answer3: encircling the rest southward along the hollow windings of the glen

question: Why was the third battalion the most terrible?
answer1: These were headless men, fighting like human beings, yet finished at the neck.
answer2: no sound save only that they waved their arms and struck their weapons together, and smote the ground with their feet impatiently

question: Why did Murtough rise impetuously off the bed?
answer1: Murtough, in his sleep and in his dreams, heard the battle-shout.

question: What happened after Murtough rose impetuously off the bed?
answer1: The wine overcame him, and his strength departed from him, and he fell helplessly upon the floor.

question: Why was all of Murtough's strength lost in fighting phantoms?
answer1: The phantoms were but stones and sods and withered leaves of the forest that he took for fighting men.

question: What did Duivsech call upon Cairnech to do?
answer1: to arise and to gather together the clans of the children of his people, the men of Owen and of Niall

question: How did Cairnech feel because Sheen guarded the fort well?
answer1: angry

question: What did Cairnech bless?
answer1: the clans of Owen and of Niall

question: What happened after Cairnech blessed the clans of Owen and of Niall?
answer1: They returned to their own country.

question: Why did Cairnech send messengers?
answer1: to seek Murtough
answer2: to draw the king away from the witch woman who sought his destruction

question: What happened whenever Murtough made any sign to go to Cairnech?
answer1: Sheen threw her spell upon the King, so that he could not break away.

question: Why did Sheen order the warriors to point their spears and javelins inwards towards the house?
answer1: so that the King would not dare to go out amongst them

question: What did Sheen do when she realized it was a night of Samhain-tide, the eve of Wednesday after All Souls' Day?
answer1: She went everywhere throughout the house, and took lighted brands and burning torches, and scattered them in every part of the dwelling.

question: Why did Sheen smile?
answer1: The King had spoken her name, for she knew by that that the hour of her revenge had come.

question: Why did Murtough suddenly scream out of his sleep?
answer1: He heard the crash of falling timbers and the noise of the magic hosts, and he smelled the strong smell of fire in the palace.

question: What happened after Murtough said Sheen's name?
answer1: She caused a great snowstorm to come round the house so that drifts of deep snow were piled against the walls, blocking the doors and chilling the folk that were feasting within the house.

question: What did Murtough do after Sheen told him he was dreaming?
answer1: He slept again and he saw a vision.

question: Where did the griffin carry Murtough to?
answer1: her eyrie on the dismal cliff outhanging o'er the ocean

question: What happened after a flame rose from the nest?
answer1: Murtough and the griffin were enveloped in the flame.

question: What happened after the king donned his arms?
answer1: He made one plunge forward seeking for the magic hosts.

question: What did the clerics find the next day?
answer1: Murtough's corpse

question: Where did the clerics carry the corpse to?
answer1: Tuilen

question: How did Duivsech die?
answer1: weakness came upon her she leaned her back against the ancient tree that is in Aenech Reil
answer2: a burst of blood broke from her heart

question: What did Duivsech do when she found her husband dead?
answer1: She struck her hands together and she made a great and mournful lamentation.

question: Where were the king and queen laid?
answer1: near the north side of the little church that is in Tuilen

question: Who did the clerics and Cairnech see coming towards them across the sward?
answer1: a lonely woman
answer2: "Sigh, Sough, Storm, Rough Wind, Winter Night, Cry, Wail, and Groan?"

question: Who was the lonely woman?
answer1: Sheen, the daughter of Sige, the son of Dian, from whom Ath Sigi or the 'Ford of Sige'

question: Who did the maiden slay?
answer1: Murtough of the many deeds, of the race of Conn and Niall, High King of Ireland and of the West

question: Why did Sheen slay Murtough?
answer1: Murtough slew her father, and her mother and sister were slain along with him, in the battle of Cerb upon the Boyne, and there was none of my house to avenge their death.
answer2: to avenge the wrong and loss he wrought on them

question: How did Sheen poison the king?
answer1: She made for him magic drink and food which took his strength away.

question: What did the clerics do after they wondered at those things?
answer1: They wrote them and revised them in a book.

question: How will the people feel when their pagan belief is replaced with Christian teaching?
answer1: confused
answer2: shocked

question: Why did Sheen dress herself up before she approached the king?
answer1: She wanted to be in a disguise.
answer2: She wanted to fool the king.
answer3: She did not want the king to suspect her.

question: Why did Sheen make her wish so long and complicated?
answer1: She wanted revenge against Murtough.
answer2: She wanted to get rid of the new religion.

question: How will Murtough feel when he hears Sheen's wish?
answer1: surprised
answer2: overwhelmed

question: How will Duivsech feel when Murtough drives her family out and follow Sheen's wishes?
answer1: devastated
answer2: upset

question: Why did Sheen tell Murtough not to reveal her name?
answer1: She did not want to be targeted.
answer2: She wanted to hide her identity from others.

question: How did the king feel towards Sheen?
answer1: fearful
answer2: admiration

question: Why did the king ask Sheen to work some great wonders?
answer1: He wanted to see her powers.
answer2: He was skeptical of her powers.
answer3: He was excited that his new bride was magical.

question: What will happen when Murtough and the hosts wake up?
answer1: They will be terrified by the battalions.
answer2: They will hear the stamping of the battalions.

question: How did Duivsech know what was going on?
answer1: She suspected the new bride was trouble.
answer2: She heard the stomping and battle-shouting.

question: How did Cairnech try to save Murtough?
answer1: He tried to invade the fort.
answer2: He tried to take Murtough away from the witch.
answer3: He tried to curse the king.

question: Why did Cairnech bless the clans of Owen and Niall?
answer1: They tried to save Murtough.
answer2: They came to Murtough's aid.
answer3: They left their own countries to try to save Murtough.

question: How will Murtough feel when he realizes he has been tricked by Sheen?
answer1: betrayed
answer2: foolish

question: Why did Sheen tell the king it was all a dream?
answer1: She did not want him to try to stop her.
answer2: She wanted to fool him.
answer3: She wanted him to suffer her vengeance.

question: What did Murtough do after Sheen told him he was dreaming?
answer1: He slept again and he saw a vision.

question: Why did Murtough have many terrible dreams and visions?
answer1: He drank the wine.
answer2: He was cursed by Sheen.

question: Why was the king dear to Sheen?
answer1: She loved him.
answer2: He treated her well.

question: How did Sheen feel killing the king?
answer1: sad
answer2: unhappy
